newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Jakarta index ends 1.18 pct up on bargain hunting.
newsitem.headline: Jakarta index ends 1.18 pct up on bargain hunting.

text.p: Jakarta share prices closed 1.18 percent higher on Tuesday after a spurt of late bargain-hunting mostly in the cigarette sector, brokers said.
The Jakarta composite index rose 7.67 points, or 1.18 percent, to close at 657.29 points after touching a day's low of 649.62 points.
Gainers led losers by 67 to 51 with 64 issues unchanged. Total volume was 336.27 billion rupiah with about 154 million shares changing hands.
"Bargain hunting in Sampoerna and Gudang Garam helped boost the index as well as overall sentiment after recent sharp falls," one broker from a foreign brokerage firm said.
He said most of the buying on tobacco counters Sampoerna and Gudang Garam originated from foreign brokerage houses, which ignited follow-up buying from the locals.
Gudang Garam and Sampoerna had been under strong pressure after reports of a new government regulation on cigarette sales.
Cigarette makers, under the new scheme, are required to allocate 10 percent of their retail sales profits to distributors.
Gudang Garam ended 400 rupiah up at 10,500 rupiah, while Sampoerna rose 700 rupiah to close at 11,175 rupiah in active trading.

"The falls were somewhat of an over-reaction, but it was understandable. Players prefered to sell their Indonesian blue chips stocks after the biggest blue chip Telkom came under heavy pressure (last week)," another broker said.

Telkom was under pressure on news reports that the government may end its monopoly over basic telephone services before the scheduled 2006 for domestic inter-city calls and 2011 for local calls, an analyst said.

He said the Tourism, Post and Telecommunications Ministry was expected to hold a press conference involving several senior government officials on Wednesday regarding Telkom's monopoly issue. Officials were not immediately available for comment.
The news reports had said the government was likely to allow a firm linked to President Suharto's brother-in-law Sudwikatmono to provide basic telecommunications services.
Telkom had denied the rumours, but analysts said they were waiting for more details from the senior government officials.
Telkom was the second most actively traded stock. It rose 25 rupiah to 3,575 rupiah.
Plywood firm Daya Sakti Unggul, listed on Tuesday, was the most actively traded at a price of 1,125 rupiah compared with its initial offering price of 950 rupiah.
Brokers ascribed the encouraging debut to news reports that plywood prices in the international market had improved in the past few months. -- Jakarta newsroom +6221 384-6364
